trans-unit.source: Configuring Azure Automation
trans-unit.target: Configuring Azure Automation

trans-unit.source: Describes steps that you must perform to configure Azure Automation for initial use.
trans-unit.target: Describes steps that you must perform to configure Azure Automation for initial use.

trans-unit.source: Configuring Azure Automation
trans-unit.target: Configuring Azure Automation

trans-unit.source: This article describes the actions you must perform to initially start using Azure Automation.
trans-unit.target: This article describes the actions you must perform to initially start using Azure Automation.

trans-unit.source: Automation accounts
trans-unit.target: Automation accounts

trans-unit.source: When you start Azure Automation for the first time, you must create at least one Automation account.
trans-unit.target: When you start Azure Automation for the first time, you must create at least one Automation account.

trans-unit.source: Automation accounts allow you to isolate your Automation resources (runbooks, assets) from the Automation resources contained in other Automation accounts.
trans-unit.target: Automation accounts allow you to isolate your Automation resources (runbooks, assets) from the Automation resources contained in other Automation accounts.

trans-unit.source: You can use Automation accounts to separate Automation resources into separate logical environments.
trans-unit.target: You can use Automation accounts to separate Automation resources into separate logical environments.

trans-unit.source: For example, you might use one account for development and another for production.
trans-unit.target: For example, you might use one account for development and another for production.

trans-unit.source: The Automation resources for each Automation account are associated with a single Azure region, but Automation accounts can manage Azure services in any region.
trans-unit.target: The Automation resources for each Automation account are associated with a single Azure region, but Automation accounts can manage Azure services in any region.

trans-unit.source: The main reason to create Automation accounts in different regions would be if you have policies that require data and resources to be isolated to a specific region.
trans-unit.target: The main reason to create Automation accounts in different regions would be if you have policies that require data and resources to be isolated to a specific region.

trans-unit.source: Automation accounts, and the resources they contain, that are created with the Azure preview portal cannot be accessed in the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: Automation accounts, and the resources they contain, that are created with the Azure preview portal cannot be accessed in the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: If you want to manage these accounts or their resources with Windows PowerShell, you must use the Azure Resource Manager modules.
trans-unit.target: If you want to manage these accounts or their resources with Windows PowerShell, you must use the Azure Resource Manager modules.

trans-unit.source: Automation accounts created with the Azure portal can be managed by either portal and either set of cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: Automation accounts created with the Azure portal can be managed by either portal and either set of cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: Once the account is created, it makes no difference how you create and manage resources within the account.
trans-unit.target: Once the account is created, it makes no difference how you create and manage resources within the account.

trans-unit.source: If you are planning to continue to use the Azure portal, then you should use it instead of the Azure preview portal to create any Automation accounts.
trans-unit.target: If you are planning to continue to use the Azure portal, then you should use it instead of the Azure preview portal to create any Automation accounts.

trans-unit.source: An Automation account may be suspended if there is an issue with your Azure account, such as an overdue payment.
trans-unit.target: An Automation account may be suspended if there is an issue with your Azure account, such as an overdue payment.

trans-unit.source: In this case, you can’t access the account, any running jobs will be suspended, and all schedules will be disabled.
trans-unit.target: In this case, you can’t access the account, any running jobs will be suspended, and all schedules will be disabled.

trans-unit.source: You will be able to view the account, but you won’t be able to see any resources in it.
trans-unit.target: You will be able to view the account, but you won’t be able to see any resources in it.

trans-unit.source: Once you correct the issue and the Automation account is enabled, you will have to enable your schedules and restart any runbooks that were suspended.
trans-unit.target: Once you correct the issue and the Automation account is enabled, you will have to enable your schedules and restart any runbooks that were suspended.

trans-unit.source: Configuring authentication to Azure resources
trans-unit.target: Configuring authentication to Azure resources

trans-unit.source: When you access Azure resources using the <link><linkText>Azure cmdlets</linkText><title></title></link>, you need to provide authentication to your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: When you access Azure resources using the <link><linkText>Azure cmdlets</linkText><title></title></link>, you need to provide authentication to your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: In Azure Automation, this is done with an organizational account in Azure Active Directory that you configure as an administrator for your subscription.
trans-unit.target: In Azure Automation, this is done with an organizational account in Azure Active Directory that you configure as an administrator for your subscription.

trans-unit.source: You can then create a <link><linkText>credential</linkText><title></title></link> for this user account and use it with <link><linkText>Add-AzureAccount</linkText><title></title></link> in your runbook.
trans-unit.target: You can then create a <link><linkText>credential</linkText><title></title></link> for this user account and use it with <link><linkText>Add-AzureAccount</linkText><title></title></link> in your runbook.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft accounts, formerly known as LiveIDs, cannot be used with Azure Automation.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft accounts, formerly known as LiveIDs, cannot be used with Azure Automation.

trans-unit.source: Create a new Azure Active Directory user to manage an Azure subscription
trans-unit.target: Create a new Azure Active Directory user to manage an Azure subscription

trans-unit.source: Log in to the Azure portal as a service administrator for the Azure subscription you want to manage.
trans-unit.target: Log in to the Azure portal as a service administrator for the Azure subscription you want to manage.

trans-unit.source: Select Active Directory
trans-unit.target: Select Active Directory

trans-unit.source: Select the directory name that is associated with your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: Select the directory name that is associated with your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: If necessary, you can change this association from Settings > Subscriptions > Edit Directory.
trans-unit.target: If necessary, you can change this association from Settings > Subscriptions > Edit Directory.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Create a new Active Directory user</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Create a new Active Directory user</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Select New user in your organization for the Type of user and do not Enable Multi-Factor Authentication.
trans-unit.target: Select New user in your organization for the Type of user and do not Enable Multi-Factor Authentication.

trans-unit.source: Note the user’s full name and temporary password.
trans-unit.target: Note the user’s full name and temporary password.

trans-unit.source: Select Settings > Administrators > Add.
trans-unit.target: Select Settings > Administrators > Add.

trans-unit.source: Type the full user name of the user that you created.
trans-unit.target: Type the full user name of the user that you created.

trans-unit.source: Select the subscription that you want the user to manage.
trans-unit.target: Select the subscription that you want the user to manage.

trans-unit.source: Log out of Azure and then log back in with the account you just created.
trans-unit.target: Log out of Azure and then log back in with the account you just created.

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted to change the user’s password.
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted to change the user’s password.

trans-unit.source: Create a new <link><linkText>Azure Automation Credential asset</linkText><title></title></link> for the user account that you created.
trans-unit.target: Create a new <link><linkText>Azure Automation Credential asset</linkText><title></title></link> for the user account that you created.

trans-unit.source: The Credential Type should be Windows PowerShell Credential.
trans-unit.target: The Credential Type should be Windows PowerShell Credential.

trans-unit.source: Use the credential in a runbook
trans-unit.target: Use the credential in a runbook

trans-unit.source: You can retrieve the credential in a runbook using the <link><linkText>Get-AutomationPSCredential</linkText><title></title></link> activity and then use it with <link><linkText>Add-AzureAccount</linkText><title></title></link> to connect to your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: You can retrieve the credential in a runbook using the <link><linkText>Get-AutomationPSCredential</linkText><title></title></link> activity and then use it with <link><linkText>Add-AzureAccount</linkText><title></title></link> to connect to your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: If the credential is an administrator of multiple Azure subscriptions, then you should also use <link><linkText>Select-AzureSubscription</linkText><title></title></link> to specify the correct one.
trans-unit.target: If the credential is an administrator of multiple Azure subscriptions, then you should also use <link><linkText>Select-AzureSubscription</linkText><title></title></link> to specify the correct one.

trans-unit.source: This is shown in the sample Windows PowerShell below that will typically appear at the top of most Azure Automation runbooks.
trans-unit.target: This is shown in the sample Windows PowerShell below that will typically appear at the top of most Azure Automation runbooks.

trans-unit.source: You should repeat these lines after any <link><linkText>checkpoints</linkText><title></title></link> in your runbook.
trans-unit.target: You should repeat these lines after any <link><linkText>checkpoints</linkText><title></title></link> in your runbook.

trans-unit.source: If the runbook is suspended and then resumes on another worker, then it will need to perform the authentication again.
trans-unit.target: If the runbook is suspended and then resumes on another worker, then it will need to perform the authentication again.

trans-unit.target: Related articles
